addition to consider when determining how to incorporate the additional local data into the original training
set so the first option is you have balanced replacement in which an equal amount of benign in the malicious
training set is replaced with new data there's unbalanced replacement in which you only replace samples in one of the
old training sets with new data balanced addition where an equal amount of new data is added to both the benign and the
malicious training sets and unbalanced addition and you only add new data to one of the old training sets so why
would you choose one versus another operationally so looking at balanced versus unbalanced you might choose to
balance your addition of new data to prevent the classifier from favoring one class over another just because there's
more of it this might not be a major issue when only slightly imbalancing the training sets depending on the
algorithms and approaches used for training your classifiers but this is certainly a concern as more and more data is added to only one training set
in the model looking at replacement versus addition there are a couple operational impacts
to consider if you choose a replacement strategy you more quickly bias the model to the new Inu samples however you do
this at the cost of losing part of the original training set if you use an addition strategy you typically increase
the time required to train the new models as well as increase storage requirements for storing those new
samples so for our experiment we tried all four approaches we did not see any
significant differences when only adding or replacing files up to 20% for a single Branch off the base model as a
result we chose unbalanced addition for the purposes of this experiment as it is the easiest to implement operationally
due to the lack of Need for additional samples or feature vectors to be provided by the
